description.en:
The course will enable students to understand what are the necessary knowledges, skills and attitudes to act as human rights educators. The course relies on the definition of human rights education as encompassing "education, training, awareness raising, information, practices and activities which aim - by equipping learners with knowledge, skills and understanding and developing their attitudes and behaviour - to empower learners to contribute to the building and defence of a universal culture of human rights in society, with a view to the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms" (Council of Europe's Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship and Human Rights Education, 2010). 

Students who complete this course will be able to apply the learning content within the practice module P2OG.02.216 and practice teaching human rights.

objectives.en: To provide a broad understanding of human rights education, its political development in the last decades, its pedagogical principles, the methodology for teaching human rights and to enable students to design educational activities and take action for human rights.

independent_work.et:
*	Reading and independent research work to map the situation of Human Rights Education in one's reality, according to the instructions in class. This individual research translates in assignments in Moodle.

*	Pair/group work, on practicing the design of an educational activity and running it.

*	Individual work on designing an Action Plan for Human Rights Education which could be implemented in student's reality, followed by its presentation in class.

grade_preconditions.et:
* Participation in all classes, with no more than 3 missed classes permitted
* Completing all modules assignemnts
* Development and presentation of an Action Plan for HRE

grade_evaluation.et:
The final result is an average of three elements:

1. Class attendance and quality of participation (20%)
- demonstrated engagement with the study materials
- participation in the class discussions and exercises

2. Completing the Moodle assignments (40%)
- doing individual research as per instructions in class and in Moodle
- understanding the applicability of the studied topic on one's own reality
- reading colleagues' assignments and giving feedback 

3. Realisation and oral presentation of an action plan (40%)
Quality criteria:
- in depth understanding of the current reality and possibilities for human rights education
- feasible actions to undertake
- convincing presentation.

resources.mandatory_materials:
Books and articles
*books are all available in the library!

- Bajaj, Monisha, ed., Human rights education: theory, research, praxis, Routledge, 2017
- Cargas, Sarita, Human Rights Education forging an academic discipline, University of Pennsylvania, 2020
- Coysh, Joanne, Human Rights Education and the Politics of Knowledge, Routledge, 2018
- Gerber, Paula, Education about Human Rights - Strengths and weaknesses in the UN Declaration on Human Rights Education and Training, 2011 (free article online)
- Keet, André, Human rights education: a conceptual analysis, Lambert academic Publishing, 2010

Manuals for educators
- Council of Europe (2012): Compass - Manual for human rights education with young people. Eds. Patricia Brander, Ellie Keen and Marie-Laure Lemineur
- Council of Europe (2011): Educating for democracy: background materials on democratic citizenship and human rights education. Eds. Rolf Gollob, Peter Krapf and Wiltrud Weidinger
- Council of Europe (2010): Growing up in democracy: lesson plans for primary level on democratic citizenship and human rights (EDC/HRE). Eds, Rolf Gollob, Peter Krapf and Wiltrud Weidinger
- Danish Institute of Human Rights (2010): Human Rights Education and Learning Methods. (www. humanrightscourses.dk/index.php?id=284)
- Northern Ireland Human Rights Commission (2008): Inspiring Practice - Resources, tools and activities for human rights education
- European Training and Research Centre for Human Rights and Democracy (2006): Understanding Human Rights - Manual on Human Rights Education (Ed. Wolfgang Benedek)
- OHCHR (2002): Handbook on National Human Rights Plans for Action
- Flowers, Nancy et al, The Human Rights Education Handbook - Effective Practices for Learning, Action and Change, University of Minnesota, 2000


Legal instruments and soft law
- UN (1993): Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action 
- UN (1996): Plan of Action for the UN Decade for Human Rights Education A/51/506/ Add.1
- CoE (2010): Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship and Human Rights Education, adopted by the Council of Europe on 11 May 2010.
- UN (2011): Declaration on Human Rights Education and Training A/HRC/RES/16/1

Movies
- UN (2012): A path to dignity: the power of human rights education (http://www.path-to-dignity.org/)
- Yad Vashem: "May Your Memory Be Love"
- 2015: "He named me Malala"
